Popular baby girl names

The following 100 baby girl names are the most popular girl names registered in England and Wales in 2022, as recorded by The Office for National Statistics (the 2023 list will be released towards the end of 2024) – and show us the latest snapshot of which names are the trending picks for new parent. Olivia and Amelia continue to head the list, as they have done for a few years now, and there are lots of other names that are also regular fixtures, including Ava, Ivy, Lily, Florence and Rosie. But shooting up this most recent list are the newly popular Maeve, Ayla, Elodie and Hallie – and making their top 100 debut are Ophelia, Ottilie, Eloise, Nova and Fatima.

Traditional baby girl names

Some baby girl names have been popular for generations, building up a real back story of tradition and familiarity. Some are timeless classics that parents pick year after year, while others wind their way up and down the most-picked names lists – some years not quite so much in favour, only to re-emerge strongly a few years later. All of them have stood the test of time and seem destined to outlast some of the more recent baby-name fads and fashions. Looking for more inspiration on lovely traditional baby girl names ? Top tips for choosing your baby girl name

You want to choose a name for your baby girl that you – and she – will love forever. No big ask, then! To make the whole process feel easier and less overwhelming, follow these top name-picking tips.

Consider girl names that mean a lot to your family. You may want to think about naming your child after a much-loved relative or perhaps there's a particular name that's been passed down your or your partner's family for generations.

Think about options from other countries. If you or your partner have a strong link with another country, choosing a baby girl name from that part of the world is a great way of honouring that connection. You may also want to look at names from places you've loved to visit on holiday.

Look at name meanings. Take a moment to consider the type of name you want your baby girl to have. Do you want a strong, powerful name or something delicate and gentle? Perhaps you like the idea of a name that reflects your love of nature or your religious beliefs or even a special time of the year?

Troubleshoot your choices. Once you’ve drawn up a shortlist of names you like, take them for a test drive to see whether they will work in reality. How does the name sound when said with your surname? What will the initials be? Will people find it easy to pronounce or will your child have a lifetime of correcting others? Is it simple to spell or will people always be making mistakes? What nicknames might people call your child? How can it be shortened?

Check how popular the girl names you like are. It’s a good idea to check out where your favourite baby girl names come in the top 100 list before you commit to one. If it's on the list, think how that makes you feel. Are you happy that your girl may probably be sharing her name with one of her classmates at school or is it super-important to you that your girl's name is as different and as distinct as possible.

Of course, what's cool and what's not fluctuates from year to year and right now there's a bit of a cool thing for place-name names and precious-stone names. When do I have to choose my baby's girl name by?

New parents in England, Wales and Northern Ireland have 42 days to register their baby’s name once he is born. If you live in Scotland, you will be expected to register your baby’s birth (and name) within 3 weeks of his birth.

Once you have picked a name, contact your local register office for an appointment to go in and register your baby’s birth.

You will need to take some identification with you to prove who you are and some registrars may ask to see your baby’s red book, which is their personal health record. When you register the birth, you will be asked your baby’s full name as well as details about when and where he was born.

The birth must be registered by the baby’s mother or father and if you are unmarried and go to the register office alone, you will have to take a declaration of parentage form signed by the other parent with you.

Indian baby girl names

Naming a baby in India is usually accompanied by a big family ceremony (on the 11th day after birth, in Hindu tradition). Immense care is taken with the name selection, with parents sometimes calling on a 'pandit' (a wise man) to cast the baby girl's astrology chart and select a letter of the alphabet that the name should begin with. Great weight is also placed on the meaning of the name and, for that reason, Indian baby girl names, whether modern or traditional, Hindi or Urdu, tend to have light-filled, auspicious, harmonious meanings and origins based in Sanskrit, or sometimes Persian or Arabic. What if I choose the wrong baby girl name?

If you get cold feet and decide you've made a mistake with the name you've picked and registered, don't worry: in the UK, you can get the name changed relatively easily at your local register office, as long as you do so within a year of your baby's birth. Animal-inspired baby girl names

Baby girl names with an animal theme are endearing and cute and speak of a strong connection to wildlife and the natural world around us. Animal-themed baby girl names can either be the actual name of an animal, such as Fawn, Sable and Wren, or can have meanings that link them to a particular animal, bird or insect. Short baby girl names

A short, sweet girl baby name is simple and effective. Neat, friendly, straightforward, 1 or 2-syllable baby girl names are quick to say and (usually) easy to spell, which means they'll be a doddle for your little girl to recognise, as she gets old enough to spot the patterns in letters and words, and, eventually, to write. About the author Helen Brown

Helen is Deputy Editor of MadeForMums, the author of Parenting for Dummies (Wiley, £17.99). She has written about parenting for Mumsnet, Pregnancy & Birth, Prima Baby, Boots Parenting Club and She Magazine and she's also been Consumer Editor of Mother & Baby. She has 3 children and a heavy-duty washing machine.

About the '100 most popular names' list

Every year in October, the Office of National Statistics publishes a list of the most popular names in England and Wales for both girls and boys. Because of the time needed to collect and process all the data, each new list is always based on names registered up to 2 years ago. So, the most recent list is based on names registered in 2022. Scotland's National Records of Scotland and Northern Ireland's Northern Ireland Statistics and Research Agency also each release their own list every year, gathered in the same way.
